Police The instant miscellaneous application was preferred by applicants Sand R who had participated in selection process initiated for filling up posts of Constables in the State of U.P. They had applied in categories of OBC-Female and SC-Female respectively. It was submitted that their claim was erroneously rejected by the State Government despite directions dated 24-7-2019 issued by the Supreme Court in Ashish Kumar Yadav, 2019 SCC OnLine SC 1968 and that candidates with lower marks than them were selected in General Female category disregarding their claim. Held: Per curiam Pursuant to the directions issued by the Supreme Court in Ashish Kumar Yadav, 2019 SCC OnLine SC 1968, selection was undertaken for 3295 posts of Police Constables in accordance with merit and consistent with reservation policy. According to the results declared, 188 posts in "General Female Category" were filled up. The last candidate appointed in the category of "General Female" had secured 274.8928 marks. Applicant 1 S belonging to OBC category had secured 276.5949 marks but her claim was not considered. 21 such applicants belonging to "OBC Female" Category who had secured more than 274.8298 are before the Court. However, no "SC Female" Category candidates who were not selected had secured more than 274.8298 marks. Thus, claim of Applicant 2 and other similarly situated "SC Female Category" candidates does not stand on same footing (Paras 18 and 19) Ashish Kumar Yadav v. State of U.P., 2019 SCC OnLine SC 1968, considered The principle that candidates belonging to any of the vertical reservation categories are entitled to be selected in "Open or General Category" is well settled. It is also well accepted that if such candidates belonging to reserved categories are entitled to be selected on the basis of their own merit, their selection cannot be counted against the quota reserved for the categories for vertical reservation that they belong. (Para 26) Indra Sawhney v. Union of India, 1992 Supp (3) SCC 217 : 1992 SCC (L&S) Supp l; R.K. Sabharwal v. State of Punjab, (1995) 2 SCC 745: 1995 SCC (L&S) 548,followed V.V. Giri v. D. Susi Dora, (1960) 1 SCR 426 : AIR 1959 SC 1318, relied on The High Courts of Rajasthan, Bombay, Uttarakhand, and Gujarat have adopted the same correct principle while dealing with horizontal reservation whereas the High Courts of Allahabad and Madhya Pradesh have taken a contrary erroneous view. The second view that weighed with the High Courts of Allahabad and Madhya Pradesh is essentially based on the premise that after vertical reservations are provided for, at the stage of accommodating candidates for effecting horizontal reservation, the candidates from reserved categories can be adjusted only against their own categories under the vertical reservation concerned and not against the "Open or General Category". The second view is erroneous and the same is rejected. The first view is affirmed as being the correct view. (Para 27) The second view may lead to a situation where, while making adjustment for horizontal reservation in Open or General Category seats, less meritorious candidates may be adjusted, as has happened in the present matter. Admittedly, the last selected candidate in Open General female category while making adjustment of horizontal reservation had secured lesser marks than the applicants. The claim of the applicants was disregarded on the ground that they could claim only and only if there was a vacancy or chance for them to be accommodated in their respective column of vertical reservation. (Para 29) The second view is neither based on any authoritative pronouncement by the Supreme Court nor does it lead to a situation where the merit is given precedence. Subject to any permissible reservations i.e. either social (vertical) or special (horizontal), opportunities to public employment and selection of candidates must purely be based on merit. Any selection which results in candidates getting selected against Open/General category with less merit than the other available candidates will certainly be opposed to principles of equality. There can be special dispensation when it comes to candidates being considered against seats or quota meant for reserved categories and in theory it is possible that a more meritorious candidate coming from Open/General category may not get selected. But the converse can never be true and will be opposed to the very basic principles which have all the while been accepted by the Supreme Court. Moreover, it would, of necessity, result in acceptance of a postulate that Open/General seats are reserved for candidates other than those coming from vertical reservation categories. Such view will be completely opposed to the long line of decisions of the Supreme Court. Any view or process of interpretation which would lead to incongruity must be avoided. The first view which weighed with the High Courts ofRajasthan, Bombay, Uttarakhand and Gujarat is correct and rational. Hence, the logical consequence must be to annul said selection and direct the authorities to do the exercise de novo in the light of conclusions arrived at. However, considering the facts that those selected candidates have actually undergone training and are presently in employment and that there are adequate number of vacancies available, it is directed that: (i) All candidates coming from "OBC Female Category" who had secured more marks than 274.8928 i.e. the marks secured by the last candidate appointed in "General Category-Female" must be offered employment as Constables in Uttar Pradesh Police. (ii) Appropriate letters in that behalf shall be sent to the candidates concerned within four weeks. (iii) If the candidates concerned exercise their option and accept the offer of employment, communications in that behalf shall be sent by the candidates concerned within two weeks. (iv) On receipt of such acceptance, the codal and other formalities shall be completed within three weeks. (v) Letters of appointment shall thereafter be issued within a week and the candidates concerned shall be given appropriate postings. (vi) For all purposes, including seniority, pay fixation and other issues, the employment of such candidates shall be reckoned from the date the appointment orders are issued. (vii) The employment of General Category Females with cut-off at 274.8928 would remain unaffected; (viii) Since it has been accepted that none of the candidates coming from "SC Female Category" had secured more marks than 274.8298, the claims of Applicant 2 and all similarly situated candidates are rejected. STATE OF U.P. 547 WP (C) No. 237 of 2020 This writ petition under Article 32 was filed by 14 female candidates pertaining to same selection praying for issuance of writ, order or directions in the nature of mandamus directing the respondents to absorb the petitioners against 375 unfilled vacancies. However, none of the petitioners securing more than 274.8298 marks. As such, their case cannot be considered on a par with Applicant 1 S and other similarly situated candidates. If there are unfilled vacancies, it is for authorities to act purely in terms of statutory provisions concerned. No case for issuance of mandamus or to pass any order directing the authorities concerned to absorb the petitioners against unfilled vacancies made out. (Paras 47 to 49) Per S. Ravindra Bhat, J. (supplementing) The views expressed by a number of High Courts and termed as "the first view" in Lalit, J.' s judgment, is the correct one, and is endorsed, and the view expressed by the Allahabad and Madhya Pradesh High Courts - called by Lalit, J. as the "second view" about the nature of the horizontal reservation for women, and the mechanism spelt out (by those judgments) to fill them, are not in accord with the previous judgments of the Supreme Court. Uday Sisode, 2019 SCC OnLine MP 5750, overruled The controversy that arises in the present round of litigation pertains to the correct method of filling the quota reserved for women candidates ("horizontal quota"). It is the complaint of the applicants, who are largely women, belonging to the Other Backward Class categories, that the State has not correctly applied the rule of reservation, and denied such OBC women candidates the benefit of "migration" i.e. adjustment in the general category vacancies. (Para 53) The U .P. Public Services (Reservation for Physically Handicapped, Dependants of Freedom Fighters and Ex-Servicemen) Act, 1993 provided for reservations to persons with disability, ex-servicemen and dependants of freedom fighters. The U .P. Public Services (Reservation for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and Other Backward Classes) Act, 1994 is the comprehensive law, enacted by the State of U.P. providing for reservation for social categories (SC/ST/OBCs). The reservations under the 1993 Act are horizontal in nature. (Para 54) The quota provided for women, as well as dependants of freedom fighters ("DFF") and ex-servicemen, are characterised as "horizontal" whereas the quotas for social groups (SCs, STs, OBCs) are characterized as "vertical". The coining of this differential terminology is underscored by the fact that the latter is sanctioned explicitly in Article 16(4), whereas the former is evolved through a process of permissible classification [Articles 14, 16(1)], although such horizontal reservations have been located additionally in Article 15(3). However, a government order was issued, applicable to all posts, on 26-2-1999 providing for horizontal reservation for women. A plain reading of the government order showed that the only stipulation with respect to treatment of horizontal reservation for women was that in a case a woman candidate was selected, she was to be adjusted against the appropriate social category she belonged to (SC/ST/ OBC/OC). However, there was no rule or direction prohibiting the adjustment of socially reserved categories of women in the general category or "open category". (Para 57) Indra Sawhney v. Yamul, (1996) 3 SCC 253, cited The features of vertical reservations are: a b C (i) They cannot be filled by the open category, or categories of candidates d other than those specified and have to be filled by candidates of the social category concerned only (SC/ST/OBC). (ii) Mobility ("migration") from the reserved (specified category) to the unreserved (open category) slot is possible, based on meritorious performance. (iii) In case of migration from reserved to open category, the vacancy in the reserved category should be filled by another person from the same specified category, lower in rank. (iv) If the vacancies cannot be filled by the specified categories due to shortfall of candidates, the vacancies are to be "carried forward" or dealt with appropriately by rules. (Para 59) Horizontal reservations on the other hand, by their nature, are not inviolate pools or carved in stone. They are premised on their overlaps and are "interlocking" reservations. As a sequel, they are to be calculated concurrently and along with the inviolate "vertical" (or "social") reservation quotas. They cannot be carried forward. The first rule that applies to filling horizontal reservation quotas is one of adjustment i.e. examining whether on merit any of the horizontal categories are adjusted in the merit list in the open category, and then, in the quota for such horizontal category within the particular specified/social reservation. (Para 60) Indra Sawhney v. Union of India, 1992 Supp (3) SCC 217: 1992 SCC (L&S) Supp l,followed The open category is not a "quota", but rather available to all women and men alike. Similarly, there is no quota for men. If the second view is accepted the result would be confining the number of women candidates, irrespective of their performance, in their social reservation categories and therefore, destructive of logic and merit. These are not to be seen as rigid "slots", where a candidate's merit, which otherwise entitles her to be shown in the open general category, is foreclosed. Doing so, would result in a communal reservation, where each social category is confined within the extent of their reservation, thus negating merit. The open category is open to all, and the only condition for a candidate to be shown in it is merit, regardless of whether reservation benefit of either type is available to her or him.
